field_reports.description:
On Thursday, July 24, 2025, at 20:06 WITA, an earthquake with a magnitude of 6.0 SR struck Poso District, Central Sulawesi. The epicenter was located at a depth of 10 km, with coordinates 2.03°S, 120.70°E, approximately 70 km southwest of Poso.

The earthquake was felt across several regions, with the following intensities based on BMKG analysis:

  • MMI IV-V in Poso,

  • MMI III-IV in Bungku,

  • MMI IV-V in Kolonodale,

  • MMI II-III in Palu,

  • MMI IV-V in Mangkutana,

  • MMI III-IV in Mappadeceng.

Fortunately, the earthquake did not generate a tsunami threat.

Impact of the Disaster

The most severely affected area was Pamona Tenggara District in Poso Regency. The earthquake impacted 1,560 households (approximately 4,680 people). The casualties include:

  • 4 individuals with severe injuries,

  • 5 individuals with minor injuries,

  • 4,680 displaced individuals,

  • 52 houses severely damaged,

  • 248 houses lightly damaged,

  • 5 places of worship,

  • 2 schools.

Post-Earthquake Situation

As of July 31, BMKG recorded 208 aftershocks with magnitudes ranging from 3.0 to 4.0 SR. Although the situation has stabilized, many residents remain concerned about potential aftershocks and have chosen to seek refuge with relatives for safety.

Health Reports

According to Puskris Kemenkes, 106 health-related cases have been reported following the earthquake, with a variety of conditions including:

  • Hypertension

  • Vertigo

  • Cold/flu

  • Asthma

  • Gastritis

  • Dyspepsia

  • Myalgia

  • Arthritis

  • Parotitis

  • Hypotension

  • Common cold

The most frequently reported condition is hypertension, with 20 reported cases.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Earthquake - 07-2025 - Earthquake Disaster in Poso District, Central Sulawesi Province

field_reports.description:
• Heavy rainfall on Sunday, 22 June 2025 caused overflow of Inggoy River and triggers flooding around the river area and impacting in total of 15 villages across 5 sub-disctrct in South Halmahera, North Maluku province. Flood water ranging from 30–100 cm

  • Impact: 4,418 households / 14,938 people affected by the floods and approximately 9,240 people evacuated into safer location. As the report circulated, around 1,522 houses affected by the floods with 4 houses sustained heavy damage, 2 bridges heavily damaged, and 1 fatality reported.

  • Responding to the floods situation, South Halmahera District authority declared a 14-day flood emergency response status from 22 June to 7 July 2025.

  • As of report circulated, floodwaters have not fully receded and post-floods debris (mud, logs and etc) inundated affected area. Displaced household are evacuating into several location. However, most of the displaced houshold sought shelter within their neighbour or relatives houses

  • Based on coordination call with PMI North Maluku provincial team, immediate and basic needs are met. Post floods activity such as environment post-floods cleaning activity is starting as affected household are returning back to their house. BPBD will start the early-recovery assessment after the emergency period ended.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Flood - 06-2025 - Floods in South Halmahera district

field_reports.description:
Floods and Landslides in East Kalimantan Province

Following heavy rainfall that began on Tuesday (May 27), several rivers in East Kalimantan—namely the Karang Mumus River, Mahakam River, Sempaja River, Segah River, and Pinang River—overflowed. This resulted in widespread flooding across parts of Samarinda City, Kutai Kartanegara Regency, and Berau Regency, with water levels ranging from 30 to 100 cm.

Impacts by Region:

  • Berau Regency:
    Flooding affected 1 sub-district, impacting 212 households / 640 people, and inundating 3 places of worship, 1 healthcare facility, and 2 educational facilities.

  • Kutai Kartanegara Regency:
    Flooding affected 1 sub-district, with 708 households / 1,859 people impacted and 708 houses submerged.

  • Samarinda City:
    Flooding affected 5 schools. In addition, landslides triggered by heavy rain affected 2 households / 6 people, resulting in 2 fatalities.

Overall Impact:

  • Total Affected: 922 households / 2,505 people

  • Casualties: 2 missing, 2 deceased

  • Infrastructure Damaged: 708 houses, 7 schools, 3 places of worship, and 1 healthcare facility

Current Conditions:

In Kutai Kartanegara, some areas have started to recede; however, upstream areas of the Mahakam River remain flooded. Data collection is currently hampered by flooded and inaccessible roads as well as continued adverse weather conditions. In landslide-affected areas, joint teams are still working to clear debris and restore access.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Flood - 05-2025 - Floods in East Kalimantan Province

field_reports.description:
Earthquake Report – Bengkulu Province

An earthquake occurred on Friday (May 23) at 02:53 AM WIB, with a magnitude of 6.3 on the Richter scale, at a depth of 10 km. The epicenter was located at coordinates 4.17°S and 102.17°E, approximately 43 km southwest of Bengkulu, in the sea.

According to the BMKG (Indonesian Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency) analysis, the earthquake was felt with an intensity of MMI IV–V in Bengkulu City, Bengkulu, and Empat Lawang; MMI IV in Kepahiang, Liwa, Rejang Lebong, Lubuk Linggau, and Seluma; MMI III–IV in Lemong, Tais, and Muko-Muko. The earthquake did not trigger a tsunami potential.

BMKG classified the earthquake as a moderate earthquake, caused by intraslab activity. The most affected areas include Central Bengkulu Regency, Bengkulu City, North Bengkulu Regency, and Seluma Regency.

As a result of the incident:

294 households / 800 people were affected

2 people were seriously injured

1 person died

27 houses were severely damaged

51 houses were moderately damaged

216 houses were slightly damaged

Damage also occurred to 1 place of worship, 7 schools, 1 meeting hall, and 1 government office.

One fatality was reported. Currently, affected residents whose houses were heavily to moderately damaged have taken refuge with nearby relatives. Electricity, which had been temporarily cut off, has been restored. Assessments are still ongoing, but are hampered by poor road access and connectivity in Seluma Regency.

The Bengkulu City Government has declared an Emergency Response Status for the Earthquake Disaster, effective for seven days, from May 23 to May 29, 2025.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Earthquake - 05-2025 - Bengkulu Province earthquake disaster

field_reports.description:
Following heavy rainfall since Thursday (April 10), the Baliem River and its tributaries overflowed, causing flooding across 22 districts in Jayawijaya Regency, including Wamena City. Water levels (TMA) ranged from 20 to 120 cm.

A total of 13,232 households or 52,928 people were affected. Around 1,300 people were displaced, and 4,714 houses, 6 schools, and 10 churches were submerged. As of now, no further damage has been reported.

Currently, the floodwaters have receded, but secondary flooding still frequently occurs. Communities are struggling to access clean water due to contamination and high mineral content.

The Jayawijaya Regency Government has declared a 14-day Emergency Response Status (TDB) for floods and landslides, effective from April 25 to May 8, 2025.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Flood - 04-2025 - Floods in the Papua Pegunungan Regency

field_reports.description:
Flood Conditions

  • Situation: Heavy and intense rainfall since Monday (03/03) night triggered overflows Ciliwung, Cikeas, Cilengsih and Kali Angke which lead to floodings in several areas.
  • Flood Affected Areas:
    • DKI Jakarta (West, East, South, North Jakarta)
    • Bodetabek (Bekasi, Bogor, Tangerang, Depok)
  • Flood level ranging from 30-300 cm across the area.
  • In Jambi province, heavy rainfall on Thursday (27/02), flooding occurred in Jambi Province, affecting three regions: Sarolangun Regency, Merangin Regency, and Sungai Penuh City. The floodwaters reached depths of 20-100 cm, impacting thousands of residents.

Disaster Impact in Jakarta, Banten and West Java

  • Total affected: 2,365 households / 9,462 people.
  • Total evacuees: 2,655 people.
  • Flooded houses: 2,093 units.
  • Details by region:
    • DKI Jakarta: 1,410 households / 5,640 people affected, 2,406 people evacuated, 1,390 houses flooded.
    • Bogor Regency: 247 households / 988 people affected, 249 people evacuated, 257 houses flooded.
    • Depok City: 40 households / 160 people affected, 40 houses flooded.
    • Tangerang City: 128 households / 512 people affected.
    • South Tangerang Regency: 242 households / 970 people affected, 256 houses flooded.
    • Bekasi City: 150 households / 600 people affected, 150 houses flooded.
    • Bekasi Regency: 148 households / 592 people affected.

Disaster impact in Jambi Province:

  • Sarolangun Regency: 5,698 households (22,879 people) affected, 5,117 houses flooded, 3 schools, and 5 places of worship impacted.
  • Sungai Penuh City: 158 households (491 people) affected, 148 houses sustained minor damage.
  • Total impact: 5,234 households (20,882 people), 5,117 houses flooded, 148 houses slightly damaged, 3 schools, and 5 places of worship affected.

Current Situation in Jakarta, Banten and West Java

  • Floodwaters have not yet receded, evacuees remain at shelters.
  • Weather forecast (04/03): Moderate to heavy rain expected from morning to afternoon.
  • BMKG Warning: Extreme weather predicted to continue until next week.
  • BNPB & DKI Jakarta Government: Weather Modification Operation ongoing until March 8, 2025.

Current Situation in Jambi Province:

  • Water levels in Sungai Penuh City are receding.
  • In Sarolangun Regency, floods remain at 100-200 cm.
  • Weather Forecast (BMKG, 03/03): Light rain expected throughout the day in Jambi.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Flood - 03-2025 - Floodings in Jambi, Jakarta, Banten and West Java - Update #1

results.name: Indonesia: Flood EAP, 2025
results.summary:
The IFRC Disaster Response Emergency Fund (DREF) has approved a total of CHF 517,485 for the implementationof the Indonesian Red Cross (Palang Merah Indonesia) Floods EAP. The approved amount consists of an allocation of CHF 316,873 for readiness and prepositioning and CHF 200,612 allocated to implement early actions once the defined triggers are met.
Allocations are made from the Anticipatory Pillar of the DREF, under the DREF appeal code MDRID027.Unearmarked contributions to DREF are encouraged to guarantee that sufficient funding is available for the EarlyAction Protocols being developed.

Floods are a recurrent and escalating disaster in Indonesia, with over 2,500 flood events recorded between 2007and 2021, affecting millions of people annually and causing extensive damage to infrastructure.
The Indonesian Red Cross has developed the Early Action Protocol (EAP) as a guide for implementing anticipatoryactions to reduce the impacts of floods based on complex analysis of flood risks with a 5-year return periodacross the country. The development of this EAP and its implementation involve coordination with national andsub-national government agencies, including the National Disaster Management Agency (BNPB), the Indonesian
Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG), Local Disaster Management Agencies (BPBD) and TheIndonesian Red Cross Community-based Disaster Preparedness volunteers (SIBAT), to ensure readiness for andtimely activation of pre-agreed early actions when defined trigger thresholds are reached.
Utilizing available weather forecasts, particularly those with an 80 per cent probability of heavy rainfall, the EAPinforms targeted early actions triggered at 6 days and at 72 hours before anticipated floods occur in line withexisting local capacities.
The EAP is targeting 2,500 households / 10,000 people and aims to reduce and mitigate the Loss of Life/Injuries:through dissemination of early warning, evacuation planning, first aid, and community feedback mechanisms;Livelihood Damage: by providing unconditional cash grants to support affected households; WaterContamination: by promoting household-level water management and hygiene; Disease Outbreaks: through health promotions.

field_reports.description:
• Eruption Overview:

    • Increased volcanic activity since January 15, 2025, at 7:15 WIT. Volcanology and Geology Hazard Mitigation Centre, changed Mount Ibu volcanic activity from Level III (orange - Watch) to Level IV (red - Warning)
    • As of reporting date, 6 villages in Tabaru District affected by volcanic ash, West Halmahera Regency, North Maluku Province.

  • Impact:

    • 600 families or 3,000 people affected volcanic ash.
    • 1,325 people evacuated to 8 shelters across West Halmahera Regency.

  • Emergency Response:

    • Disaster Emergency Status declared for Mount Ibu's eruption (January 15–28, 2025).
    • Alert level raised from Level III (SIAGA) to Level IV (AWAS) on January 15, 2025.

  • Seismic Activity (as of January 23, 2025):

    • 1,397 eruption-related quakes.
    • 83 avalanches, 2,515 emission quakes.
    • 299 harmonic tremors, 23 tornillo earthquakes.

  • Health Situation:

    • 152 cases of illnesses reported in evacuation shelters.
    • Most common illnesses:
      • Upper Respiratory Infections (52 cases).
      • Hypertension, Dermatitis, Myalgia, Dyspepsia, Common Cold, Fever, Wounds, Gastritis, Vertigo, Scabies, and Diarrhea.

  • Safety Measures (Volcanology and Geology Hazard Mitigation Centre):

    • No activities allowed within 5 km of the eruption center and 6 km north of the crater opening.
    • recommended to use masks to prevent respiratory issues from volcanic ash.
    • Community who live around river area has to stay vigilant on cold lava flow.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Volcanic Eruption - 01-2025 - Mount Ibu volcanic eruption and increased activity

field_reports.description:
• Mt. Lewotobi Laki-laki erupted on Tuesday (June 17) at 5:35 PM (GMT +8), sending an ash column approximately 10,000 meters above its crater.

  • Indonesian Center for Volcanic and Geological Disaster Mitigation escalates the The volcano's alert status from Level III (Alert) to Level IV (Warning), the highest level. Volcanic tremors continues which indicates volcanic activities remain active. 

  • Six districts and two islands have been impacted by volcanic ash from the eruption.

  • The East Flores District authority has declared a state of emergency, effective from February to August 2025.

  • The eruption caused travel disruption with 12 flights at Komodo International Airport (Labuan Bajo sub-district) were cancelled due to the volcanic ash.

  • Since the eruption in 2024, community who used to live within the disaster prone area (less than 5 kilometers from Lewotobi crater) has permanently relocated to safer area. East Florest district authority has provided and constructed permanent shelter to affected community.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Volcanic Eruption - 06-2025 - Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki

field_reports.description:
• On Monday (03/11), Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki increased its volcanic activity and at 11.57 PM the mountain erupted with maximum amplitude of 47.3 mm as long as 1450 seconds.
  • Centre of Volcanic and Geology Disaster Mitigation or PVMBG, has increased Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki volcanic activity level from Level III (Siaga or Alert) to Level IV (Awas or Caution) the highest level. 
  • Due to the eruption, around 2,735 household or 10,295 people from 2 sub-districts namely Wullanggitang and Ile Bura affected by the volcanic ash. On the other hand, community of Dulipali village, Ile Bura sub-district evacuated to Lewolaga village in Titehena sub-district as three temporary site prepared already within the village.
  • A total of 10 fatalities reported due to collapsing roof in Klantalo village. In additions, 7 schoold facilities and 23 houses damaged by the eruption. 
  • As the mountain remain active and currently at the highest activity level, PVMBG advise the community to stay clear in radius of 7 KM from the crater, to remain vigilant of cold-lava flows and to wear face-mask to reduced health risk.
  • Weather forecast indicates that rain will occur in Kupang, Larantuka and Ende area for the next 3-days.
field_reports.summary: IDN: Volcanic Eruption - 11-2024 - Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki Eruption

field_reports.description:
Situation Update :

  • An earthquake with the magnitude of 5.2 occurred on 18 September 2024 at 9:41 AM (GMT +7). Epicenter located at land with the depth of 10 KM below ground (shallow EQ).
  • The earthquake can be felt throughout Lembang, Parompong, West Bandung, Baleendah, Garut and Majalaya districts in West Java Province.
  • Based on Indonesian Met service or Indonesian Meteorological Service or Badan Meteorologi, Klimatologi dan Geofiska, the Earthquake did not trigger tsunami
  • As of report circulated, there are 5 aftershocks recorded with maximum magnitude of 3.1

field_reports.description:
1. Heavy rainfall on several districts in West Sumatera province has caused flash flood to Padang Panjang city, Tanah Darat district and Agam district. 
  2. It is believed the flash flood was actually cold-lava flow from Mount Marapi which erupted in December 2023 and remain active with currently at level 3 (orange level)
  3. As of reporting date, there are 50 people reported dead, 27 people misisng, 23 people injured and 3,396 people displaced by the flash flood. In addition, the flash flood damaged 5 schools, 11 mosque, 1 government building, 15 bridges and 50 hectare of paddy field. 
  4. Access from Padang Panjang city to Pada city is completely cut off.
  5. Responding to the situation, Agam district, Padang Panjang and Tanah Datar districts authority declared 'emergency response' status to their respective area starting from 12 May 2024 to 25 May 2024

field_reports.description:
1. On Tuesday (30/04), Indonesian volcanic center (PVMBG) reported Mt. Ruang erupt and actively spewing volcanic ash.
  2. Considering the scale and intensitiy of the eruption, PVMBG changed Mt. Ruang Status from level 3 to level 4 on Tuesday (30/04)
  3. Responding to the situation, PVMBG updated Mt. Ruang "volcanic disaster prone area" from 5 KM around the crater to 7 KM around the crater.
  4. As the safe area is now expanded, there are several area located in Tagulandang island (located next to Ruang island) considered as not safe. PVMBG recommended all communities who are live within the radius of 7 KM to evacaute to safer location.  
  5. Due to volcanic activities, 6,267 people evacuated from Tagulandang Subdistrict (Island) to Siau Island, Manado city, North Minahasa or Bitung.
  6. Communities who are live in Ruang island, will be permanently rellocated to South Bolaang Mongondow district. The government will support the process and provide necessary support to the community
  7.  As per reporting period, eruption is continuing and Mt. Ruang remain at level 4 (Red)
  8. More than 3,200 houses and more than 50 units of community facilities (school, health facility, markets, bridge and etc) damaged by the Mt Ruang volcaninc activities.

field_reports.description:
1. A lanslide repoted on Saturday 13 April 2024 at 11.30 PM (GMT +8) affecting Palangka village, Tana Toraja district, South Sulawesi Province.
  2. The landslide was triggered by heavy rainfall and unstable ground formation in the area. There were two landslide reported which affecting Lembang Randan Batu village and Manggau village.
  3. The landslide killed 20 people, injuring 2 people and displacing 77 people. 
  4. Based on rapid assessment, 4 houses damaged by the landslide.
  5. Responding to the situation, emergency response decared for Tana Toraja district from 13 April 2024 until 14 April 2024.

field_reports.description:
Floods situation in West Sumatera Intense rainfall occurred in West Sumatra Province from Thursday (07/03) to Friday (08/03), resulting in floods and landslides at 10 district/city namely Kab. Pesisir Selatan district, Padang city, Padang Pariaman district, Agam district, Solok district, Pasaman Barat district, Limapuluh district, Solok city, Pasaman city, Pasaman Timur district and Mentawai district.

·       BPBD West Sumatera reported that 26 casualties, and 11 individuals still missing. 

·       Approximately 33,172 HHs (116,292 Individuals) have been effected. Reported 1,603 houses and  20, 004 public facilities and building have been inundated, 871 Houses experiences severe damage, 2 houses have been washed away, 23 bridges have been disrupted and 28 schools along with rice field and livestock affected by the floods.

·       According to Indonesian Meteorological Service or Badan Meteorologi, Klimatologi dan Geofiska (BMKG), light rain is forecasted to continue until 13 March 2024 while on 14 March 2024, clear weather forecasted for West Sumatera province

 

Impact Update

                            

Pesisir Selatan District

·       Floods and landslides in Pesisir Selatan District have impacted a total of 29,143 HHs (76,178 individuals), with 76,178 people displaced. The disaster has sadly resulted in 16 fatalities and 7 people are still missing. Floods have inundated 20,004 buildings, including 14 severely damaged houses, and 8 bridges have been disrupted. Currently, access to clean water remains challenging for the community, with electricity and internet connection disruptions.

Kota Padang

·       Floods inundated  8 sub-districts in Kota Padang. In total of  10,150 HHs or 35,299 individuals have been affected, with 3,374 people displaced. Additionally, 10,150 houses have been inundated, 2 washed away, and 1 healthcare facility inundate. Additionally, Floods and heavy rainfall have triggered landslides in 6 different locations.

Padang Pariaman

·       A total of 15 sub-districts were affected by the Floods. Preliminary data indicates that 2,958 Houses have been affected by flooding, with 800 houses inundated at water levels ranging from 30 to 300 cm. A total of 15 districts and 32 villages have been affected by these disasters. Reported 3 fatalities. Furthermore, some affected community evacuated to safer locations.

Agam District

·       Floods in Agam District have affected 3 areas, namely  Tanjung Raya, Palembayan, and Jorong Sigidan Malalak Utara. A total of 49 HHs or 209 individuals affected by the floods. As per reporting date 144 people have been evacuated from their inundated houses.

Kota Solok

·       Floods Solok Kota Solok has impacted a total of 283 HHs, comprising 813 individuals, including 15 childrens and 9 elderly people

Pasaman Barat District

·       Five sub-districts in Pasaman Barat District have been inundated by floods due to heavy rainfall since Thursday afternoon until the evening of March 7, 2024. In total of 31 HHs or 191 people, were affected by the floods

Limapuluh city

·       Three sub-districts in the city have been inundated by floods. In total of 24 HHs or 100 people, were affected by the floods

Solok District

·       One sub-districts have been inundated by floods. In total of 10 HHs were affected by the floods

Pasaman Timur district

·       Three sub-districts have been inundated by floods. In total of 191 HHs were affected by the floods

Mentawai district

·       One sub-district affected by the floods. Assessments are ongoing at the field

 

As per reporting date, Pesisir Selatan district is the most affected district in West Kalimantan. Floods has started to recedes in most of the area.

Heavy rainfall since 29 December 2023, caused flooding in Rupit and Karang Jaya sub-district in North Musi Rawas, South Sumatera province. As per reporting period, the floods has receded. However, the floods are now affecting Karang Dapo and Rawas Ilir sub-district. In total there are 3000 household or approximately 12,000 people affected by the floods. 

Besides affecting the community, the floods also damaging bridge which linking the affected district to neighboring area, inundated 5 schools, 3 praying facilities and 2 health facilities. Based on rapid assessment report, there are two evacuation centre established in the district and 317 people registered in both of the evacuation centre.

field_reports.description:
Situation Update

In March 2023, the Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) issued advice that the intensifying El Niño phenomenon and positive Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) may cause a drought during the dry season in Indonesia. As explained by Head of the BMKG in her statement to the press, El Niño and the Indian Ocean Dipole, both of which are cause by temperature changes in the Pacific and Indian oceans respectively, are anticipated to occur simultaneously during this year's dry season.

The concurrence of both phenomena in the latter part of 2023 is likely to exacerbate impacts of El Niño, leading to decreased rainfall in some areas of Indonesia throughout the dry season. A number of regions are predicted to experience rain intensity at below normal levels, or drier than usual conditions. 

BMKG has provided historical data from a similar situation in 2019, when El Niño coincided with IOD, and El Niño in Indonesia reached “Moderate” status, triggering more than 4000 hotspots. This saw significant impacts to communities, including forest fires in a number of provinces in Indonesia, leading to a loss in productivity of around 5.2 billion USD according to World Bank data.

According to BMKG, climate phenomena recorded in Pacific Ocean waters in May and June of 2023 could lead to El Niño in June, which could cause the region to feel warmer. Anomalies in Pacific Ocean temperatures have been growing, with the index reaching 0.8, concerningly close to the threshold of 1, at which point the El Niño status goes from “Weak” to “Moderate”. Currently, Trends show a consistent increase and there is an 80% chance that the El Niño status will escalate.

The figures below, issued by BMKG, illustrate monthly rainfall forecast from June to November 2023. The forecasts indicate a high probability that several Indonesian provinces will see rainfall intensity of around 0-20mm below normal during August and September 2023. BMKG has circulated an early warning of potential drought causing water scarcity, particularly in Java and Bali, and the southern part of Sumatra. 

The BMKG website (CEWS | Climate Early Warning System (bmkg.go.id)), as at the first ten-day reporting period for August 2023, identifies a Red (Alert) status for the following districts/cities:

1. Bali: Karangasem

2. Central Java: Boyolali, Karanganyar, Klaten, Semarang, Sragen, Sukoharjo

3. East Java: Bangkalan, Banyuwangi, Bojonegoro, Bondowoso, Jombang, Kediri, Kota Pasuruan, Kota Surabaya, Madiun, Mojokerto, Nganjuk, Kabupaten Pasuruan, Probolinggo, Sidoarjo, Situbondo

4. East Nusa Tenggara: Bima, Lombok Tengah, Lombok Timur, Manggarai Timur, Rote Ndao, Sumba Tengah, Sumba Timur

While the number of areas classified as “Red” remains unchanged from the third 10-day period of July, there is significant increase to the number of areas classified as “Orange” (Standby), from 23 to 42 areas, an increase of almost 100%. Meanwhile, the total number of areas with “Yellow” (Caution) status has risen from 11 to 89, indicating a spike of over 800% for areas showing signs of initial stages of drought. 

Based on information collected from the media and PMI Situation Reports, water scarcity has been broadly reported. In some areas, the government at Province/District/City level have declared “initial emergency (siaga darurat)” status, which is akin to an activation for early action relating to potential impacts of decreased rainfall. Affected provinces include East Nusa Tenggara, East Java, West Java, and South Kalimantan.

In other areas, including Mojokerto, Lumajang, Jember, and Pasuruan, local governments have declared ‘emergency’ status.

These status declarations, to some extent, corroborate BMKG’s warnings and forecasts. 

Government Response:

Early warning information has been circulated by the Indonesian Government to all sectoral ministries, ensuring preparedness for the potential impacts of drought. Preparation measures include ensuring sufficient food stocks and urging governments at sub-national level to maintain vigilance in readiness for potential impact of El Niño.

RCRC response

In a number of areas, PMI has been providing support to those impacted by the drought, including water distribution for daily consumption and conducting awareness raising activities. 

As auxiliary to the Government, PMI has been providing support to those impacted by the drought, including water distribution for daily consumption and conducting awareness raising activities. Currently, there are PMI team from across four Provinces namely Banten, West Java, Central Java and West Kalimantan provinces who are already on the field providing support to the affected community. In total of 56 personnel mobilized to operate 49 unit of water trucks on daily basis. As per this report circulated, PMI managed to distribute 965,000 liter of water across the four provinces.

PMI NHq has developed a national operational plan to respond to the impact of El Niño, including drought. The following plan has been established by PMI NHq in readiness:

- Mobilizing water trucks from the regional warehouses, prioritizing provinces which are located in red zones

- Providing clean water through water trucking

- Implement drought awareness raising and preparedness session to the communities at risk

results.name: IDN: Drought - 2023-08 - Drought due to El Nino and IOD Phenomena
results.summary:
Situation Update

In March 2023, the Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) issued advice that the intensifying El Nio phenomenon and positive Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD) may cause a drought during the dry season in Indonesia. As explained by Head of the BMKG in her statement to the press, El Nio and the Indian Ocean Dipole, both of which are cause by temperature changes in the Pacific and Indian oceans respectively, are anticipated to occur simultaneously during this year's dry season.

The concurrence of both phenomena in the latter part of 2023 is likely to exacerbate impacts of El Nio, leading to decreased rainfall in some areas of Indonesia throughout the dry season. A number of regions are predicted to experience rain intensity at below normal levels, or drier than usual conditions.

BMKG has provided historical data from a similar situation in 2019, when El Nio coincided with IOD, and El Nio in Indonesia reached Moderate status, triggering more than 4000 hotspots. This saw significant impacts to communities, including forest fires in a number of provinces in Indonesia, leading to a loss in productivity of around 5.2 billion USD according to World Bank data.

According to BMKG, climate phenomena recorded in Pacific Ocean waters in May and June of 2023 could lead to El Nio in June, which could cause the region to feel warmer. Anomalies in Pacific Ocean temperatures have been growing, with the index reaching 0.8, concerningly close to the threshold of 1, at which point the El Nio status goes from Weak to Moderate. Currently, Trends show a consistent increase and there is an 80% chance that the El Nio status will escalate.

The figures below, issued by BMKG, illustrate monthly rainfall forecast from June to November 2023. The forecasts indicate a high probability that several Indonesian provinces will see rainfall intensity of around 0-20mm below normal during August and September 2023. BMKG has circulated an early warning of potential drought causing water scarcity, particularly in Java and Bali, and the southern part of Sumatra.

The BMKG website (CEWS | Climate Early Warning System (bmkg.go.id)), as at the first ten-day reporting period for August 2023, identifies a Red (Alert) status for the following districts/cities:

1. Bali: Karangasem

2. Central Java: Boyolali, Karanganyar, Klaten, Semarang, Sragen, Sukoharjo

3. East Java: Bangkalan, Banyuwangi, Bojonegoro, Bondowoso, Jombang, Kediri, Kota Pasuruan, Kota Surabaya, Madiun, Mojokerto, Nganjuk, Kabupaten Pasuruan, Probolinggo, Sidoarjo, Situbondo

4. East Nusa Tenggara: Bima, Lombok Tengah, Lombok Timur, Manggarai Timur, Rote Ndao, Sumba Tengah, Sumba Timur

While the number of areas classified as Red remains unchanged from the third 10-day period of July, there is significant increase to the number of areas classified as Orange (Standby), from 23 to 42 areas, an increase of almost 100%. Meanwhile, the total number of areas with Yellow (Caution) status has risen from 11 to 89, indicating a spike of over 800% for areas showing signs of initial stages of drought.

Based on information collected from the media and PMI Situation Reports, water scarcity has been broadly reported. In some areas, the government at Province/District/City level have declared initial emergency (siaga darurat) status, which is akin to an activation for early action relating to potential impacts of decreased rainfall. Affected provinces include East Nusa Tenggara, East Java, West Java, and South Kalimantan.

In other areas, including Mojokerto, Lumajang, Jember, and Pasuruan, local governments have declared emergency status.

These status declarations, to some extent, corroborate BMKGs warnings and forecasts.

Government Response:

Early warning information has been circulated by the Indonesian Government to all sectoral ministries, ensuring preparedness for the potential impacts of drought. Preparation measures include ensuring sufficient food stocks and urging governments at sub-national level to maintain vigilance in readiness for potential impact of El Nio.

RCRC response

In a number of areas, PMI has been providing support to those impacted by the drought, including water distribution for daily consumption and conducting awareness raising activities.

As auxiliary to the Government, PMI has been providing support to those impacted by the drought, including water distribution for daily consumption and conducting awareness raising activities. Currently, there are PMI team from across four Provinces namely Banten, West Java, Central Java and West Kalimantan provinces who are already on the field providing support to the affected community. In total of 56 personnel mobilized to operate 49 unit of water trucks on daily basis. As per this report circulated, PMI managed to distribute 965,000 liter of water across the four provinces.

PMI NHq has developed a national operational plan to respond to the impact of El Nio, including drought. The following plan has been established by PMI NHq in readiness:

- Mobilizing water trucks from the regional warehouses, prioritizing provinces which are located in red zones

- Providing clean water through water trucking

- Implement drought awareness raising and preparedness session to the communities at risk

field_reports.description:
1. The earthquake with a magnitude scale of 5.6 RS occurred on 21 Nov 2022 at 13:21:10 WIB, located at 6.84 South Latitude, 107.05 East longitude at a depth of 10 Km.
  2. The tremors was felt strongly about 3 – 10 seconds across the affected areas including in Sukabumi district, Sukabumi City, Bandung district, Cianjur district, Bogor district, Bogor city, Jakarta, and Bekasi city.
  3. According to BMKG,  the earthquake did not trigger tsunami warning and has recorded 127 aftershocks, with biggest magnitude being 4.2 Richter scale and smallest being 1,5 Richter scale
  4. 3 most impacted areas are Cianjur district, Sukabumi district and Bogor District
  5. BNPB data as per 22 November the earthquake has resulted in 62 people casualties, displaced 13,784 people, and injured 326 people. About 5.405 are scattered in several evacuation points.  Final data on these impact are still ongoing.
  6. Impact to housing units and infrastructure  include damaged to 3.257 housing units, 4 health facilities, 14 educational facilities, 4 government buildings, 6 houses of worship, 2 bridge, and disrupted PLN Cianjur district (state-owned electricity company) affecting 358 sub-station and therefore services to 17,900 customers.
  7. Several roads have been cut off due to landslides.
  8. As the power grid went out, communications network are also disrupted.

field_reports.description: Indonesia has been struck by a highly contagious viral Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD), affecting the population of cattle farming. As of 2nd July 2022, Government of Indonesia reported that FMD outbreak has been detected in 20 Provinces and 227 districts or city. FMD has infected in total of 313,636 cattle, 105,675 of which has recovered, 2,734 died and 1,948 had to be slaughtered (with severe condition). Responding to the outbreak situation, Government of Indonesia through Indonesian Disaster Management Authority (Badan Nasional Penanggulangan Bencana or BNPB) has declared outbreak status that began from 29 June 2022 until 31 December 2022.

field_reports.description:
Mount Semeru, which is located on the border of Lumajang and Malang districts, erupted on Saturday (4/12) and at 2:50 p.m. Mount Semeru Volcano Observation Post (PPGA) at Gunung Sawur Post, Poncosumo hamlet, Sumberwuluh Village, Candipuro sub-district recorded flood lava vibrations or hot cloud avalanches with a maximum amplitude of 20 millimeters-25 millimeters Seismographs for 5160 seconds.  At the moment, Mount Semeru remains at level II (Alert) status. Accuweather Air's radar detected high levels of pollution which can negatively impact the elderly, pregnant women, disabled people and children. The government through PVMBG advised the public to comply with the recommendations :  not to engage in activities within a radius of 1 km from the crater/peak of Mount Semeru and in the direction of crater openings in the south-southeast sector, including around river basin areas/valleys that originate at Mount Semeru within a radius of 5 km,  especially along Besuk Kobokan, Besuk Bang, Besuk Kembar, and Besuk Sat. 

As of 17 December 2022 Mount Semeru is at Level-3 (Siaga or Alert)

According to Indonesian Meteorological, Geophysical and Climatological Agency (Badan Meteorologi, Klimatologi dan Geofisika or BMKG), the EQ did not trigger tsunami. No aftershock recorded, as per this report circulated.
The EQ can be felt throughout Central Java, East Java, Jogjakarta, Bali and Lombok Province with various shake level. According to BNPB, the reported damaged from 16 regional disaster management agency includes : 
1. Malang district: 173 damaged houses, 3 health facilities, 9 schools, 14 mosques, 2 office buildings and 1 community center hall.

field_reports.description:
Since 30 March 2021, the movement of this cyclone Seroja has brought an extreme weather including heavy rainstorm in several provinces of Indonesia. On 4 April 2021, following days of heavy rainfall, flash floods and landslides swept through eight districts and a city in East Nusa Tenggara and West Nusa Tenggara. 

In East Flores, flash floods affected seven villages. As of 6 April 2021, there were 71 reported deaths and 23 others injured. The death toll is expected to rise since there are 23 missing peoplesearches for those missing are continuing. Approximately 1,361 people were displaced in several evacuation centers across the district. The flash floods also damaged 213 houses and eight public facilities. 
In Lembatawhere PMI has an ongoing operation in response to Ili Lewotolok Eruption torrential rains caused solidified lava to tumble down the slopes of the volcano and swept through Jontona village. As of 7 April 2021, approximately 9,044 people have been affected by the flash floods and cold lava flows. There were 37 reported deaths and 98 others injured. The death toll is expected to rise as there are 30 missing individuals. These events also 958 people to neighboring villages or evacuation centers. About 329 houses, 32 public facilities, and 15 bridges were damaged or destroyed. 
In Alor, flash floods swept through three villages. As of 6 April 2021, there were 26 reported deaths, this figure is expected to rise since 20 individuals are still missing. Flash floods also damaged or destroyed 360 houses and 18 public facilities. Access to the affected areas is still restricted because roads are blocked by debris carried by landslides. 
In East Sumba, flash floods and landslides caused Lambanapu dam to overflow, inundating five villages. Around 1,803 households (7,212 people) were affected. The floods also  109 households (475 people). Information from the site is still limited; however, there have been no reported death so far. 
In the province capital, Kupang, floods inundate six sub-districts. About 743 households/2.190 people were affected. Thus far, there has been one reported death. Floodwaters inundate 657 houses and 10 hospitals. 
In Malaka, there have been three reported deaths. Approximately 1,154 houses and 65 public facilities were damaged or destroyed. 
In West Sumba, 63 households (284 people) were affected, and 54 houses were damaged or destroyed. 
In Rote Ndao, 153 households (672 people) were displaced, and 12 houses were damaged or destroyed. 
In Ngada, six households were affected, four houses and three public facilities were damaged or destroyed.


In West Nusa Tenggara province, the cyclone also triggered flash floods and landslides in Bima, North Lombok, and Dompu districts.
 Information from West Nusa Tenggara is still very limited. Based on PMIs situation report dated 7 April 2021, there have been two reported deaths. About 9,415 households (28,808 people) were affected. About 5,333 houses were damaged or destroyed. Floodwaters inundated 49 schools, 25 place of worship, 71 public facilities, 350 hectares of farmland, 1,158 hectares of fish farm. Four bridges were also damaged or destroyed. 
Information flow from the sites is still restricted due to power outages, communication shutdowns, and the remoteness of the affected areas. Not to mention, access to the affected population is also restricted because roads are blocked and covered in thick mud and debris. Data is yet to be ascertained. According to preliminary figure, 11,434/53,476 people have been affected by these events. According to BNPB, 13,230 people have been forcibly displaced from their homes. There have been 150 reported deaths and 146 others injured. The death toll is still expected to rise since there are still 55 missing individuals. About 1,962 houses in East Nusa Tenggara were damaged or destroyed, meanwhile 9,415 houses in West Nusa Tenggara were inundated. Major damage to 99 public infrastructures and at least 16 bridges has been reported.

field_reports.description:
A strong earthquake with a magnitude of 6.2 was felt in Majene, West Sulawesi Province on Friday morning (15/1), at 1:28:17 Western Indonesia Time (or 02.28 WITA, local Indonesia time).  The epicenter was located at 2.98 South Latitude and  118.94 East Longitude (or 6 km northeast of MAJENE-SULBAR).  The quake did not trigger tsunami warning. 
	According to BMKG, the EQ was a type of shallow earthquake that occurred due to local fault activity. Monitoring results show there was one foreshock (M 3.1) and six aftershocks with a maximum magnitude of 4.1
	The earthquake was felt for about 5-7 seconds quite strongly in Majene district and  Polewali district, caused the local community to panic.
	Currently, people are stay out of their houses in anticipation of aftershocks. 
	The electricity and communication network are temporarily disrupted. 
	BPBD Majene informed there are 3 points of landslides along the Majene-Mamuju main road (road access was cut off), and the road access from Makassar - Mamuju cannot be accessed due to many landslide points but road access from Palu-Mamuju is safer and can be accessed.

field_reports.description:
Heavy rainfall since Tuesday, 5 January 2021, caused Martapura and Riam river to overflow, flooding several sub-districts in Banjar. As of 12 January,  there are 7 inundated  sub districts;  Karang Intan,  East Martapura, . Martapura,  Astambul,  Sungai Pinang, Pengaron and Tabuk River with water level of 20-100 cm
	Heavy rainfall has been occurring in Tanah Laut since 7 January 2021 causes severe flooding. The situation worsens due to the ongoing high tide. Flooding impacts nine sub-districts (Pelaihari, Bati-bti, Kurau, Bumi Makmur, Tambang Ulang, Bajuin, Takisung, Jorong, and Kintap). In some areas the water level reaches 150 cm. 
	Due to the recurring heavy rainfall, as of 14 January,  the flooding have widen to Tapin District, Banjarbaru City, Balangan and Hulu Sungai Tengah District. 
- Flooding in Tapin Regency was observed at 01.00 local time, occurred in Binuang Subdistrict, Raya Belanti Village.
- In Balangan district, floods occurred because of the overflowing of the Balangan and Pitap Rivers, affecting  Tebing Tinggi sub-District (Mayanau Village, Gunung Batu, Sungsum, Ju'uh, Bumbu'an Simpang, Simpang Nadung and Tebing Tinggi), and Awayan sub-district (Putat Basiun Village, Awayan Market, Badalungga , Badalungga Hilir, Pulantan and Muara Jaya). 
- In Banjarbaru, flooding is caused by high intensity rain which  overflowed the Kemuning River. Flooding was observed at around 01.10 local time with a water level of 50 - 90 cm. Two sub-districts affected in this regency are Kemuning Village (Banjarbaru sub-district) and Guntung Payung Village (Landasan Ulin sub-district)
- In Hulu Sungai Tengah district, flooding occurred on Wednesday (13/1), at 23.00 local time.  Two sub-districts were inundated, namely Barabai and Hantakan. 

	Flooding also occurred in Hulu Tengah Selatan district, inundated 6 sub-districts; Loksado, Padang Batung, Kandangan, Angkinang, Telaga Langsat and Sungai Raya, with water levels reaching 150 cm
	The water level is still increasing due to recurring rain. According to BPBD Kota Banjarbaru, the flood has receded at several points.

field_reports.description:
On 5 November 2020 at 12.00 Western Indonesian Time (Waktu Indonesia Barat, WIB), the Centre for Research and Development of Geological Disaster Technology (Balai Penyelidikan dan Pengembangan Tekonologi Kebencanaan Geologi, BPPTKG) raised an alert level from 2 (advisory, waspada) to 3 (watch, siaga) after increasing activity of Merapi Volcano, which is located on the island of Java on the border between Central Java and Yogyakarta. An alert level 3 means that the volcano may soon erupt and warrants a danger zone of up to 5 kilometres from the main crater.  
BPPTKG has reminded the district government of Magelang, Sleman, Klaten, and Boyolaliareas that will be affected by Merapi Volcano eruption to be prepared because 30 villages in these districts are located within Disaster-prone Area. As a result, the government of Sleman, Magelang, Klaten have declared Disaster Emergency Alert (Tanggap Darurat Bencana) in their respective districts, while the government of Boyolali is prepared to follow suit. In addition, BPPTKG has also urged for a halt to all activities in Disaster-prone Area level 3 (Kawasan Rawan Bencana III, KRB III), these include all tourism activities (in particular hiking) and mining activities around river flowing from the volcano.
field_reports.summary: Merapi Volcano Eruption

results.name: Merapi Volcano Eruption

field_reports.description:
On Saturday, 28 November 2020, Indonesias Centre for Vulcanology and Geological Disaster Mitigation (Pusat Vulkanologi dan Mitigasi Bencana Geologi  PVMBG) reported a significant increase of incandescent avalanches from Semeru Volcano. Three days later, on Tuesday, 1 December 2020, at around 01.23 Western Indonesia Time (Waktu Indonesia Barat  WIB (GMT +7)), the volcano erupted, emitting lava flows from its active Jonggring Saloko Crater and blasting volcanic ash to areas in its vicinity. The eruption was followed by pyroclastic flows, that traveled towards the southeast direction and affecting areas within a 2,5 to 11 kilometres radius from the volcanos peak. As of today, the volcanos status remains at alert level 2 (advisory, waspada). PVMBG, however, has recommended for a halt to all hiking and tourism activities and warrants a danger zone of up to 4 kilometres from the summit.  

According to BNPB, 1,298 people from two sub-districts Pronojiwo and Candipuro in Lumajang have been significantly affected by the eruption. As of 4 December 2020, at least 550 people from the abovementioned sub-districts have been evacuated to two evacuation centres in Supiturang (300 people) and Mt. Sawur watch post (250 people). There have been some reports of casualties and damages. One individual has been reported missing, dozens of livestock killed, several vehicles destroyed, and agricultural areas covered in volcanic ash.  

As of 4 December 2020, Lumajang District government has declared disaster emergency alert (Tanggap Darurat Bencana) within its administrative area. Thus far, the response has been delivered in a timely manner. Delivery of services such as emergency field kitchen and distribution of relief items have been initiated. At the moment, one of the most concerning issues is COVID-19 because East Java Province is classified as a high-risk area. In Lumajang District alone, there are 138 active COVID-19 cases. Evacuation centres must be managed properly to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmission.
field_reports.summary: Semeru volcanic eruption, Lumajang District

results.name: Semeru volcanic eruption, Lumajang District

field_reports.description: Semeru volcano in East Java Province is erupted by emitting lava-flow from its active Jonggring Saloka crater, at the southeastern side of the summit. On 28 November 2020, The Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (PVMBG) reported the significant rise of the amount of incandescent avalanches from a lava-flow traveled at most one kilometers down the south-east flank. On 1 December 2020, 01.23am WIB (GMT+7) and hot plumes from the incandescent avalanches emitted from the peak (visible at night) traveled two to eleven kilometers down Besok Kobokan at the south east sector around the summit.  	Administratively, Semeru volcano is nestled in two districts: Malang and Lumajang Districts, in East Java Province.  The status level remained at 2  Caution, waspada (on scale of 1-4) and the public was recommended not approach the crater within a 4-km radius. The access for climbing and tourism have been closed, following the increasing volcanic activities. BPBD Lumajang reported that rain mixed with ash fell in the surrounding areas of the summit, which potentially can bring pyroclastic flows. 1,298 people from two sub-districts Pronojiwo and Candipuro in Lumajang have been significantly affected by the eruption. As of 4 December 2020, at least 550 people from the abovementioned sub-districts have been evacuated to two evacuation centres in Supiturang (300 people) and Mt. Sawur watch post (250 people).As of 4 December 2020, Lumajang District government has declared disaster emergency alert (Tanggap Darurat Bencana) within its administrative area.

field_reports.description:
Ili Lewotolok volcano in Lembata District, East Nusa Tenggara (NTT) erupted on Friday, 27 November 2020 at 05.57 Central Indonesia Time (GMT+8). The Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (PVMBG) reported that Ili Lewotolok was spewing out an around 500 meter-high column of ash above its summit (around 1,923 meter above sea level) westward, greyish to black colored for the initial eruption and gradually changed to thinner color. With this intensity of ash and the recorded data on the current volcanic quakes, the volcanic activity of Ili Lewotolok was categorized as high, with the potential of more eruptions to happen in near future. PVMBG issued recommendation that no resident, visitor and tourist is allowed to have any activity, including hiking, climbing, within the crater area of the volcano and within a 2 km radius from the summit. 	A second eruption occurred on Sunday, 29 November 2020 at 09.45 Central Indonesia Time (GMT+8).  In this second eruption, an around 4,000 meter-high-column of grey ash was emitted from the peak, with thicker grey colour eastward and westward. The eruption was recorded with a maximum amplitude of 35 mm and a duration of 600 seconds.
The status of Ili Lewotolok volcano is at the Caution level (Level II  Waspada), since 7 October 2017. It is believed that Ili Lewatolok had erupted violently several times around 1660s, 1800s and 1920s, and some of these eruptions had devastated the Lembata island.
On Monday 30 November 2020 up to 09.00 AM Central Indonesia Time, there have been seven eruptions recorded. As a result, PVMBG increased the status of the volcano from alert level 2 (advisory, waspada) to level 3 (watch/alert, siaga). This status warrants a danger zone of up to 4 kilometers from the crater. 
As of 1 December 2020, Lembata Distict government has declared disaster emergency alert (Tanggap Darurat Bencana) within its administrative area.  There was no immediate reports of casualties or major damage due to the eruptions.  However, 4,628 people from 17 villages in Ile Ape Sub-district and 9 villages in Ile Ape Timur Sub-district had been evacuated across 7 evacuation centers.
field_reports.summary: Ili Lewotolok volcano eruption, Lembata District, East Nusa Tenggara Province

results.name: li Lewotolok volcano eruption, Lembata District, East Nusa Tenggara Province
